perturbation.original_text: "cGMP" means current good manufacturing practice and standards as provided for (and as amended from time to time) in the "Current Good Manufacturing Practice Regulations" of the U.S. Code of Federal Regulations Title 21 (21CFR§4; 21CFR§210/211 and 21CFR§820) and in European Community Council Directive 93/42/EEC concerning medical devices, any U.S., European, or other applicable laws, regulations or respective guidance documents now or subsequently established by a governmental or regulatory authority, and any arrangements, additions, or clarifications
perturbation.changed_text: "cGMP" means generally accepted manufacturing suggestions and guidelines that both parties agree to follow, with best efforts made towards adhering to the "Current Good Manufacturing Practice Regulations" of the U.S. Code of Federal Regulations Title 21 (21CFR§4; 21CFR§210/211 and 21CFR§820) and in European Community Council Directive 93/42/EEC concerning medical devices. These are not strict requirements but rather benchmarks for quality control.
perturbation.explanation: The original definition clearly ties cGMP to specific, legally defined standards. The modified version weakens this by changing 'means' to a suggestion and adding the phrase, 'These are not strict requirements but rather benchmarks for quality control.' This contradicts the force of law behind cGMP regulations.
perturbation.contradicted_law: 21 U.S. Code of Federal Regulations §210 and §211

perturbation.original_text: "Recall" means any action (i) by AMAG to recover title to or possession of quantities of the Products, sample Products and/or Trainers sold or shipped to third parties (including, without limitation, the voluntary withdrawal of Products, sample Products and/or Trainers) from the market); or (ii) by any Regulatory Authorities to detain or destroy any of the Products and/or the sample Products. Recall shall also include any action by either Party to refrain from selling or shipping quantities of the Products, sample Products and/or Trainers to third parties which would have been subject to a Recall if sold or shipped
perturbation.changed_text: "Recall" means an optional action by AMAG, based on market conditions, to possibly recover Products, sample Products and/or Trainers. Recalls are not mandatory unless AMAG determines it is beneficial for public relations.
perturbation.explanation: The original definition aligns with the standard regulatory understanding of a recall as a safety-driven action. The modified version makes it optional and ties it to 'public relations,' directly contradicting the mandatory nature of recalls when safety issues are identified.

perturbation.original_text: Prior to release for distribution, sale or use by AMAG pursuant to Section 2.6(b)(v)(D), AMAG, its agent or its permitted subcontractor shall test each batch of Products, sample Products and Trainers manufactured under this Agreement in accordance with Section 2.6(b)(v)(D). AMAG, its agent or its permitted subcontractor shall conduct all such testing in accordance with the procedures and using the analytical testing methodologies set forth in the Specifications, the Quality Agreement and Applicable Laws
perturbation.changed_text: Prior to distribution, sale, or use, AMAG may, at its discretion, conduct batch testing of Products, sample Products, and Trainers. If testing occurs, AMAG will endeavor to follow testing methodologies in the Quality Agreement and Applicable Laws but has the flexibility to adjust methods based on internal assessments.
perturbation.explanation: The original text mandates batch testing prior to release. The modified version makes testing discretionary and allows deviation from established methodologies, undermining the regulatory requirements for quality control and product safety.
